p: When looking further at intrahost evolution of the flu, studies find that moderately deleterious mutations in influenza may remain in the population over several chains of transmission [ 27, 28]. Although these mutations may not be systematically removed through purifying, or negative, selection, they also do not become fixed within the population [ 29]. However, computational models show that deleterious mutations can impact the overall evolutionary trajectory of influenza by restricting the rate of antigenic change of the virus [ 30, 31].
